queue.fact_text: In 1929, Mother Teresa arrived by sea in Calcutta to begin a life’s work among the city’s poorest residents. She would spend decades in Kolkata’s streets and slums, turning an unknown journey into a global symbol of service and controversy around charity and dignity.

queue.fact_text: Also in 1929, King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes suspended his country’s constitution and dissolved parliament, inaugurating the so‑called January 6th Dictatorship. His royal coup aimed to suppress ethnic conflict but instead deepened tensions that would haunt Yugoslavia for generations.

queue.fact_text: On January 6, 1947, the same Earth whose crust Wegener described became a canvas for the first commercial round‑the‑world air routes; decades later, on this day in 1967, Operation Deckhouse Five began as U.S. Marines and South Vietnamese troops launched an amphibious assault in the Mekong Delta. It was one of several short but intense coastal operations that tried to mix naval power with jungle warfare.

queue.fact_text: On January 6, 1989, Satwant Singh and Kehar Singh were executed in India for their roles in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, carried out by her own Sikh bodyguards. The killing and its aftermath triggered anti-Sikh pogroms and left a deep scar in India’s political and religious landscape.

queue.fact_text: In 1993, Indian Border Security Force personnel killed 55 civilians in Sopore, Jammu and Kashmir, after militants attacked a patrol, and set much of the town’s market ablaze. The Sopore massacre became one of the most cited examples of state violence in the conflict over Kashmir.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.fact_text: On January 6, 1994, Olympic figure skater Nancy Kerrigan was attacked with a police baton at the U.S. Championships, in a plot orchestrated by associates of her rival Tonya Harding. The scandal turned an elegant sport into tabloid theater and sparked long‑running debates about class, media, and female rivalry.

queue.fact_text: Also on this date in 1995, a suspicious chemical fire in a Manila apartment led police to uncover Project Bojinka, a sprawling terrorist plot. The plan included blowing up multiple airliners over the Pacific and even crashing a plane into CIA headquarters, foreshadowing tactics later used in the 9/11 attacks.

queue.fact_text: On January 6, 2005, a Norfolk Southern freight train collided with a parked train in Graniteville, South Carolina, rupturing a tank car and releasing about 60 tons of chlorine gas. The toxic cloud killed nine people, injured hundreds, and forced the evacuation of thousands in one of the worst chemical spills in U.S. rail history.

queue.fact_text: That same day in 2005, Edgar Ray Killen, a former Ku Klux Klan organizer, was indicted for the 1964 murders of civil rights workers Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner in Mississippi. More than 40 years after the crime, his trial became a symbol of how slowly, yet persistently, justice can move in confronting racial terror.

His Epiphany cantatas were once ephemeral Sunday pieces, yet centuries later they’re studied, performed, and streamed, proving that even modest premieres can ripple far beyond their moment.

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back
episode.description:
In this first Morning Drop of 2026, Yasmin opens a space for quiet reflection on the nature of transitions. The episode traces a personal journey that began three years ago, when a sudden injury on New Year’s Day turned a desire for movement into a mandatory season of stillness.

Through the story of a broken knee and the slow process of relearning to walk, the narrative explores the difference between being strong and being aware. It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

published.fact_text: In 1912, German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presented his radical theory of continental drift, suggesting that Earth's continents were once joined and have been slowly drifting apart ever since. His idea was mocked for decades, but it later became the foundation of plate tectonics and transformed our understanding of how planets evolve.

published.fact_text: On the Night of the Big Wind in 1839, one of the most violent storms in Irish history tore across the island, destroying or damaging over 20% of Dublin’s houses. The storm was so unforgettable that, for decades, some Irish people used surviving it as an unofficial age test for old-age pensions.

published.fact_text: In 1838, Alfred Vail and his colleagues demonstrated a telegraph system that used sequences of dots and dashes—an early version of what became Morse code. Their invention turned lightning into language, allowing information to travel faster than any human or horse for the first time in history.

published.fact_text: In 1725, J. S. Bach led the first performance of his chorale cantata "Liebster Immanuel, Herzog der Frommen" (BWV 123) for Epiphany, weaving complex counterpoint around a humble congregational hymn. The piece was part of an ambitious project to write a different cantata for almost every Sunday and feast day of the church year.

published.match_reason: Bach’s sacred architecture of sound pairs well with the episode’s cinematic neo-classical mood, both inviting a slow, reverent immersion in something larger than oneself.

published.fact_text: A year earlier, in 1724, Bach unveiled another Epiphany cantata, "Sie werden aus Saba alle kommen" (BWV 65), inspired by the biblical image of travelers bringing gifts from faraway Saba. The music shimmers with exotic colors, reflecting how Europeans of Bach's time imagined distant lands they would never see.

published.fact_text: On January 6, 1641, the first Parliament of Quillín was convened during the Arauco War, bringing Spanish colonial authorities and Mapuche leaders together in Chile. It produced one of the earliest formal treaties in the Americas recognizing an Indigenous people's autonomy over their own territory.
